snippet.textDisplay:
So two things ...

1) if after Archway, i'd have stopped it would have cost me £1.50 (reduced to £1.00 - see below) and then WAITED for over 20 minutes so that the OSI didn't happen at Upper Holloway, it would have started a second £1.50 (£1.00) journey to take me to Barking - in effect 'splitting' the one journey over two legs.

2) i have a Gold Card Railcard which gives me 1/3 off off-peak Oyster journies, so what is normally £1.50 gets reduced to £1.00 - and that's the same reason why the incomplete journey charge of normally £5.60 gets reduced down to £3.70.
snippet.textOriginal:
So two things ...

1) if after Archway, i'd have stopped it would have cost me £1.50 (reduced to £1.00 - see below) and then WAITED for over 20 minutes so that the OSI *didn't* happen at Upper Holloway, it would have started a second £1.50 (£1.00) journey to take me to Barking - in effect 'splitting' the one journey over two legs.

2) i have a Gold Card Railcard which gives me 1/3 off off-peak Oyster journies, so what is normally £1.50 gets reduced to £1.00 - and that's the same reason why the incomplete journey charge of normally £5.60 gets reduced down to £3.70.

snippet.textDisplay: Temporary OSIs were introduced between Aldgate and Aldgate East during the 2012 Olympics. TfL ignored my lobbying to make them permanent. The route is sensible as the Hammersmith and City line usually has a 10 minute service interval, while competing lines have 3 or less.
snippet.textOriginal: Temporary OSIs were introduced between Aldgate and Aldgate East during the 2012 Olympics. TfL ignored my lobbying to make them permanent. The route is sensible as the Hammersmith and City line usually has a 10 minute service interval, while competing lines have 3 or less.

My guess is they haven't down it to protect revenue on Southern with passengers coming from South to NE London without going into Zone 1. (The reason behind Shoreditch High Street being in Z1).

snippet.textDisplay: We have “out of system transfers” between subway stations here, there used to be more, but they’ve cut them back to just one, between Lexington Ave/59th Street on the 4-5-6-N-R-W and Lexington Avenue 63rd Street on the F-Q since. Plus you can have a free transfer on your Metrocard for approximately 2 hours between a bus or a subway, but if you take the Staten Island Railroad (which is free to enter at any station aside from St George Ferry Terminal) all the way to the ferry and exit through the turnstiles (only station in the city with pay to exit) it gives you 2 free transfers. The ferry is also free, so technically it’s 3 free transfers. (Doesn’t stop people from getting out at the stop before the ferry and walking 1/2 mile to not pay at all.)
snippet.textOriginal: We have “out of system transfers” between subway stations here, there used to be more, but they’ve cut them back to just one, between Lexington Ave/59th Street on the 4-5-6-N-R-W and Lexington Avenue 63rd Street on the F-Q since. Plus you can have a free transfer on your Metrocard for approximately 2 hours between a bus or a subway, but if you take the Staten Island Railroad (which is free to enter at any station aside from St George Ferry Terminal) all the way to the ferry and exit through the turnstiles (only station in the city with pay to exit) it gives you 2 free transfers. The ferry is also free, so technically it’s 3 free transfers. (Doesn’t stop people from getting out at the stop before the ferry and walking 1/2 mile to not pay at all.)

snippet.textDisplay: You can do this in Washington DC if you exit from Farragut North (Red line) and walk outside to Farragut West (Orange/Blue/Silver lines). They did this when the smart cards were introduced several years ago and it avoided needing a tunnel between the two stations.
snippet.textOriginal: You can do this in Washington DC if you exit from Farragut North (Red line) and walk outside to Farragut West (Orange/Blue/Silver lines). They did this when the smart cards were introduced several years ago and it avoided needing a tunnel between the two stations.

snippet.textDisplay:
If Primrose Hill station still exists today. Then it would of been a OSI (Out of Station Interchange) as it’s closer to Chalk Farm Northern Line station. If only London Overground introduced a new Stratford-Watford Junction service via Primrose Hill (and Willesden Junction low level) where Class 378 and Class 710 trains can change voltage just like at Drayton Park & Farringdon/City Thameslink.

Plus when the Class 710s does start operating on the Lea Valley Lines and Romford-Upminster Line. Please do a video of the Class 710 trains including at Chingford, Enfield Town & Cheshunt.
snippet.textOriginal:
If Primrose Hill station still exists today. Then it would of been a OSI (Out of Station Interchange) as it’s closer to Chalk Farm Northern Line station. If only London Overground introduced a new Stratford-Watford Junction service via Primrose Hill (and Willesden Junction low level) where Class 378 and Class 710 trains can change voltage just like at Drayton Park & Farringdon/City Thameslink.

Plus when the Class 710s does start operating on the Lea Valley Lines and Romford-Upminster Line. Please do a video of the Class 710 trains including at Chingford, Enfield Town & Cheshunt.

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting that you like the Bombardier trains. They've gotten a rather bad reputation in Canada. There's been delays after delays on the delivery of trains to the TTC.  They've gotten a subsidy for the C series of airplanes, and ended up selling it to airbus. They gave bonuses to the executive right after getting that subsidy which made them seem really out of touch with the general public. They are on a rather tight leach and have likely lost a major contract as a result of the pileup of problems there's been theses last few years.
snippet.textOriginal: Interesting that you like the Bombardier trains. They've gotten a rather bad reputation in Canada. There's been delays after delays on the delivery of trains to the TTC.  They've gotten a subsidy for the C series of airplanes, and ended up selling it to airbus. They gave bonuses to the executive right after getting that subsidy which made them seem really out of touch with the general public. They are on a rather tight leach and have likely lost a major contract as a result of the pileup of problems there's been theses last few years.

snippet.textDisplay: Good to see that the gates open now with an exceeded maximum journey time. Back when I had one, many years ago when ticket offices were still staffed, the gates didn't open, and I got a "Seek Assistance" even though there were enough funds on my Oyster card to cover two maximum fares. It took a while to get that sorted out while the agent grilled me about what route I took and why it took so long.

snippet.textDisplay: In Munich, we have no barriers at stations, just time limits on the tickets. Short hop = 1 hr; 4 zones (i.e. max) = 4 hours. The only rule is that you have to keep going in one direction. Therefore you could buy a ticket in the city centre, leave the ststion and walk all the way to the airport station (4 zones). This would take about four hours, so you see the system works.
snippet.textOriginal: In Munich, we have no barriers at stations, just time limits on the tickets. Short hop = 1 hr; 4 zones (i.e. max) = 4 hours. The only rule is that you have to keep going in one direction. Therefore you could buy a ticket in the city centre, leave the ststion and walk all the way to the airport station (4 zones). This would take about four hours, so you see the system works.

snippet.textDisplay: Hang on. I have a 16-18 oyster card and I had to change from Monument Station to Bank Station (District Line to Central Line) tapped out of Monument (took £1.20 from my card) and walked to Bank Station tapped in and took the Central Line. I then tapped out at Holborn and it took £1.20 again. So I paid twice and Monument to Bank should be a OSI
snippet.textOriginal: Hang on. snippet.textDisplay:
11:55 There's something wrong with that table of time limits, and it seems to have misled Geoff.
Geoff says it gives more time on Friday evenings, because column 2 says "after 19.00 Friday". However, it must really mean "Monday to Friday after 19.00", which it also says (with an erroneous comma). It's the rest of Monday to Friday, not included in column 1 "Monday to Friday 04.30 - 19.00".
snippet.textOriginal:
11:55 There's something wrong with that table of time limits, and it seems to have misled Geoff.
Geoff says it gives more time on Friday evenings, because column 2 says "after 19.00 Friday". However, it must really mean "Monday to Friday after 19.00", which it also says (with an erroneous comma). It's the rest of Monday to Friday, not included in column 1 "Monday to Friday 04.30 - 19.00".

snippet.textDisplay: So, unless I'm terribly mistaken, making this trip as a two-leg journey will save Geoff £1.70, which just happens to be the price of a 355ml hot tea from the Starbucks across the street from the Archway station — just what you need for a ~20 minute wait. I love it when a plan comes together... 😎

That’s my OSI love 😂

snippet.textDisplay:
Was thinking before clicking on the video, will he time out? Yup :/


I use the fenchurch to monument OSI to get greggs on a Friday morning. Got to get from barrier to barrier in 20 mins.

Maybe a way to get more total time is to start at a outer national rail Station. Or even Gatwick!.
You can travel though more zones quicker, yet get more time. Then do the OSIs

snippet.textDisplay:
This is an interesting idea and video Geoff. However I do wonder what TfL would prefer you to do - do they agree with you breaking your journeys multiple times and spread out your travelling on London Overground & London Underground or would they rather you travel from Harrow and Wealdstone to Willesden Junction to Gospel oak and then Gospel Oak to Barking?
Best wishes and take care. Kind regards, Peter Skuce. St Albans. Hertfordshire.
snippet.textOriginal:
This is an interesting idea and video Geoff. However I do wonder what TfL would prefer you to do - do they agree with you breaking your journeys multiple times and spread out your travelling on London Overground & London Underground or would they rather you travel from Harrow and Wealdstone to Willesden Junction to Gospel oak and then Gospel Oak to Barking?
Best wishes and take care. Kind regards, Peter Skuce. St Albans. Hertfordshire.

snippet.textDisplay: The CTA in Chicago has these, too. They’re only used between certain stations downtown but any transfer (even if you’re not coming from the other connecting station) is free at those stations. This works at State/Lake on the loop elevated, Lake on the Red line, Washington on the Blue line, Harold Washington Library on the loop elevated and Jackson on both the Red and Blue line. All other stations with connections allow you to transfer without exiting the station.
snippet.textOriginal: The CTA in Chicago has these, too. They’re only used between certain stations downtown but any transfer (even if you’re not coming from the other connecting station) is free at those stations. This works at State/Lake on the loop elevated, Lake on the Red line, Washington on the Blue line, Harold Washington Library on the loop elevated and Jackson on both the Red and Blue line. All other stations with connections allow you to transfer without exiting the station.
